paragraph.paragraph: Metric Evaluation panel is the place to do metric evaluation. After selecting a metric from the "Select metric" area and setting an input domain in the "Setup input domain" area, you can click the run button to start metric evaluation. You can start metric evaluation with and empty input domain and the result will be always zero.
Let's first have a look at the buttons in the main toolbar, see the following figure in which the main toolbar is highlighted:

../../../../../images/eiffelstudio/metrics_tool/debug_run_icon.png Defining an input domain
Start metric evaluation Press this button to start evaluating current selected metric.

../../../../../images/eiffelstudio/metrics_tool/debug_stop_icon.png Defining an input domain
Stope metric Press this button to terminate running metric evaluation.

../../../../../images/eiffelstudio/metrics_tool/metric_send_to_archive_icon.png Defining an input domain
Send last result to metric history After a metric evaluation, this button will be sensitive, and clicking it will record the evaluated metric as well as it's input domain and result to metric history. So you can evaluate it again.

../../../../../images/eiffelstudio/metrics_tool/metric_run_and_show_details_icon.png Defining an input domain
Keep detailed result when evaluating metric Normally, evaluating a metric will give you a number as result, but sometimes, you want to investigate into those items which makes up that value. For example, evaluating Classes metric over base library gives you 242, which means there are 242 classes in base library, and sometimes, you want to know who are they. With this option enabled, you'll have a detailed result listed in detailed result panel after metric evaluation. This option only has effect when evaluating basic metrics, because the detailed result has no meaning for derived metrics (linear or ratio metrics) in general. Suppose you have a linear metric defined as 5 * Classes, then the notion of detailed result has no meaning. Another use of this option is for performance: keeping detailed result can be quite expensive in some cases, such as when you calculate the metric Lines of code for a large system, which may result in hundred of thousands of lines in the result. So turn it off in such as case may be a good idea.

../../../../../images/eiffelstudio/metrics_tool/metric_filter_icon.png Defining an input domain
Filter result which is not visible from input domain If this option is enabled, all non visible items from input domain will be filtered out. For definition of "non visible" items, please see documentation for criterion is_visible.

../../../../../images/eiffelstudio/metrics_tool/context_sync_icon.png Defining an input domain
Automatically go to result panel after metric evaluation If this option is enabled, metric tool will switch to detailed result panel after metric evaluation.

../../../../../images/eiffelstudio/metrics_tool/metric_quick_icon.png Defining an input domain
Define quick metric Sometimes, you want to calculate some metrics which are not defined already, for example, find a feature which is named "foo". And it may be just a one time thing, so there is no need to go to metric definition panel, define and save a metric and then go back to evaluation panel and run it. Quick metric is designed for this situation, you can defined any basic metric in the quick metric definition area, it's the same as the basic metric definition area in metric definition panel and then run it.
